user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_removeattr:
```c
int lfs_removeattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path, uint8_t type) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_removeattr(%p, \"%s\", %"PRIu8")", (void*)lfs, path, type);

    err = lfs_removeattr_(lfs, path, type);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_removeattr -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_removeattr:
static int lfs_removeattr_(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path, uint8_t type) {
    return lfs_commitattr(lfs, path, type, NULL, 0x3ff);
}
...
static int lfs_commitattr(lfs_t *lfs, const char *path,
        uint8_t type, const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    lfs_mdir_t cwd;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    uint16_t id = lfs_tag_id(tag);
    if (id == 0x3ff) {
        // special case for root
        id = 0;
        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &cwd, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &cwd, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_USERATTR + type, id, size), buffer}));
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No use of the Standard Library function memcmp (or any other byte-wise comparison) is present in the provided code fragments. The shown functions only call other functions (LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE, lfs_removeattr_, lfs_commitattr, lfs_dir_find, lfs_dir_fetch, lfs_dir_commit) and build tags/arguments; they do not perform any string comparisons themselves. The use of "%s" in LFS_TRACE is a format specifier for logging, not a string comparison. Because no memcmp calls or direct byte-wise comparisons of null-terminated strings appear in these fragments, there are no suspicious locations here for Rule 21.14. If investigation of other modules (e.g., implementations of lfs_dir_find, lfs_dir_commit, or any underlying helpers/macros) is desired, those source locations should be provided since they could contain memcmp usage; they are not part of the supplied code and therefore are not flagged.
